Guest lecture on ethics in ux research

Part of

Notes for John

  • I have the vague assumption that this course is very much about ethical challenges in or through ethnographic research. While thinking about my talk, I organically landed in the area of ethical challenges solved by ethnographic research. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs even something you‚Äôre interested in. Please let me know.
  • I could easily fill 30 minutes on this talk setup. There‚Äôs a little bit of interaction up front, because I‚Äôd want to get a sense of what their perspectives are on this method.

Initial ideas

  • What steps do we take to ensure our research is ethical?
  • What ethical challenges are produced by research?
  • What ethical challenges are produced by a lack of research?
    • Thinking for users
    • Operating on the assumption that users can‚Äôt tell us what they want because we don‚Äôt use the appropriate methods
    • Enterprise UX lends itself to unethical product practices by installing consultants to act on behalf of users, as ‚Äúsmarter, better informed, better educated‚Äù versions of them
  • Getting buy-in for ethnographic research is difficult in enterprise SaaS because subject matter experts ‚Äúget in the way‚Äù (‚Äúresearch for the sake of research‚Äù)
  • What ethical challenges can impact-driven startups run into (while thinking they‚Äôre ethical by virtue of impact-driven nature?)

Talk setup

  • Intro
    • Question for students: sell me on ethnographic research for my project
  • Case study: building a UXR practice in an educational technology startup
    • Startup trajectory: from pizza nights to little UX
    • Challenges: scalability, sustainability, lack of maturity (picking methods vs. ‚Äútalking to users‚Äù)
    • Opportunities:
      • Principles: Proper research, accessibility (evangelism), atomic, continuous
      • Identifying touchpoints for recruitment (sales funnel, dashboard, churn, consulting, support, social media)
    • Benchmarking:
      • Which schools are ‚Äúhealthy customers‚Äù, what do they have in common?
      • UXers using research methods accordingly
        • Ethnographic research: research planning makes it more ethical
      • Coaching non-researchers in research
    • Results:
      • Grew seniority of designers
      • Fostered a culture of informed opinions
      • Better advocating for users
      • Research as a tool for stakeholder management

Thoughts I won‚Äôt include but want to remember

  • Le Guin‚Äôs story reminds me so much of what happens in Big Tech: looking at it from the outside, it seems as though designers either drink the Kool-Aid or walk away entirely. Does anybody stay and fight?
